summary_points.title: Sensex and Nifty Dip Over 1%
summary_points.summary: The Indian benchmark indices witnessed a significant downturn as the Sensex plunged 849.37 points (1.04%) to close at 80,786.54, while the Nifty 50 declined 255.70 points (1.02%) to end the session at 24,712.05. Broad‐based selling across sectors erased nearly ₹6 lakh crore in investor wealth, marking one of the steepest single‐day falls in recent memory.

summary_points.title: 50% US Tariffs Weigh on Sentiment
summary_points.summary: With the US imposing an additional 25% tariff on Indian exports—bringing the total to 50%—market participants grew cautious, leading to a weak opening and intra-day pullback. While this escalation has dampened near-term sentiment, strategists view it as a temporary aberration likely to be resolved swiftly, especially after US Treasury commentary hinting at renewed bilateral engagement.

summary_points.title: Sectoral Divergence: Exports Under Pressure, Domestic Demand Holds Up
summary_points.summary: Export‐oriented sectors faced sustained selling pressure amid tariff headwinds, dragging key heavyweight stocks lower. In contrast, domestic demand-driven segments such as FMCG and consumer discretionary offered relative stability, while banking, IT, and realty stocks came under renewed selling interest despite pockets of resilience in consumer durables.

summary_points.title: Global Cues and Weak Opening Signals
summary_points.summary: Asian markets were mixed—Japan’s Nikkei and Topix in the green, South Korea’s Kospi higher and Kosdaq lower—while Hong Kong futures pointed to a subdued start. US equities closed at record highs overnight, but domestic pre-market indicators, including Gift Nifty trading around 24,650 (a discount of 80-odd points to futures), signaled a negative bias for the opening bell.

summary_points.title: Technical Charts Turn Bearish
summary_points.summary: On the technical front, the Sensex formed a pronounced bearish candle and is maintaining a lower‐top formation on intraday charts, reinforcing a negative near-term outlook. Key support levels around 80,500 for Sensex and 24,600 for Nifty 50 will be pivotal; a failure to hold could open the door to further downside.

summary_points.title: Analyst Insights on Key Triggers
summary_points.summary: Market experts recommend keeping a close watch on foreign institutional flows, global market momentum, and any policy interventions aimed at cushioning trade frictions. Ajit Mishra of Religare Broking highlights the resilience in domestic demand sectors, while VK Vijayakumar of Geojit Investments believes the tariff spike will be seen as a short-lived issue with diplomatic solutions on the horizon.

performing_sectors.explanation: Buoyed by resilient domestic demand, consumer stocks like HUL and Marico have attracted sustained buying.
Insulated from export tariffs, healthcare names have held up on strong local consumption and steady earnings.
Domestic financial plays continue to draw buyers as local investors position for India’s intact growth story.

underperforming_sectors.explanation: Export-oriented tech firms such as HCL Tech have been sold off on US tariff concerns and profit-taking.
Power utilities like Power Grid and NTPC lagged amid broad market weakness and foreign fund outflows.
Sun Pharma and other pharma exporters dipped under the weight of additional US tariffs and market rotation.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s sharp market pullback was driven primarily by the onset of 25% US punitive tariffs on Indian exports, which spooked exporters and added to already weak global cues, while continuous foreign institutional outflows compounded the sell-off. Banks and export‐oriented sectors saw the heaviest selling pressure, wiping out over ₹4 lakh crore in market value, even as defensive segments like FMCG displayed relative resilience. Investors also remain watchful of broader policy moves, including potential GST reforms, and any company-specific developments that could influence near-term sentiment.
